Bottled. Orange coloured. Earthy English hops in the aroma and in the flavour with notes of grapefruit. Some bitterness in the finish. Light to medium body.

Golden amber with a thick, creamy tan head, well retained.  Toast and toffee in the aroma.  Earth and toast up front, with a moderately bitter hoppiness.  The bitterness fades allowing the earthy, moderately sweet maltiness to take over in the finish.
one tasty bitter, probably one of the best ive had.  floral aroma with note of chocolate and currant.  the flavor is of sweet malt balanced by a proper amount of hops; it is medium bodied.

Cloudy pour with medium frothy head offers a faintly peppery nose with a bready sweet character. Palate is a bit thin, but was smooth and even. Flavor is malt sweet with a toffee and a nice, dry Golding hops finish. A nice homage of an ESB that doesnt try too much.

The aroma has toffee, caramel, nuts, yeast, and resin hops. The appearance is red brown with a small head. The flavor has brown sugar, nuts, toffee, toasted malt, and lightly bitter hops. The palate is smooth and buttery. The aftertaste is bitter with caramel. Pretty good.

copper color with a white head. aroma of toffee and some roasted nuts. aroma just isnt very hoppy.  bitter flavor with quite a bit of sweet nutty toffee. medium body. lively carbonation. finish is fairly bitter but somewhat watery. the sweet malt and the nuttiness seem to be  too much in this beer. decent beer  just not bitter enough.

Wow this beers is sadly underrated.  Pours a nice amber gold.  Unfiltered with a little white head.  Looks the part of an ESB.  Smells a little sweet, when i first poured it i was a little put off by the smell because it was kind of pleasant, but I didnt want it to taste like that.  Not to worry, it starts off with a nice bitter citrus hop flavor that matures into a slighly floral bitter, as it goes down you get this really nice kick of caramel at the end.  This is a fantastic ESB.  Well done rogue.

From a 22 oz. distinctive Rogue capped brown bomber bottle with a blurb and info about the bitter on the side of bottle. Made a good appearance, poured a semi-hazy, honey hued caramel with a foamy, bubbly topped pale tannish-white head that quickly reduced to a thin bubbly lacing. Had a sweet caramel malty aroma, a touch of honey, citric hoppiness and, of course, a distinctive fruity Pacman yeastiness. Good carbonation and a smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. Had a citrus hop bitterness at first, a fruity flavor the blends into the citric flavor, a little herbal hoppiness as well, a background caramel maltiness, some toasted qualities and a dry hoppiness with some dry Pacman flavor in the finish.

Youngers Special Bitter. True to its style, a proper English bitter. A no nonsense bitter. A nice hoppy aftertaste. The proper color, the proper foam. It is nice and refreshing, but it lacks the little extra. I would say its a bitter  but not a special.

Had the Fat Heads Ale at Fat Heads, which is guess is the same as this, just bottled under a different name.  I didnt think it was all that. Seemed a wee bit thin.  Was a good compliment to my food though.

Bomber[ labeled Summits Wayside Cliff Hanger Ale] poured a clear dark amber with a small, lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, malt and earthy hops. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of carmel, earthinessand some fruity notes with a nice lingering bitter finish.

650 ml bottle. Clear deep amber with nice off-white head. Moderately spicy hoppy aroma with well balanced fruity malt backbone. Flavor is pretty good but the body s thinner than what i expected from the aroma. Finishes nice & bitter. Good drink.

In honor of the Seahawks securing themselves in the annals of superbowl history, I drink a Rogue!  It was the closest beer, geographically that I had, not that it matters.  Not that I really like the Seahawks very much.  Just an excuse to have another.  Reddish hue with small white head.  Sweet hop nose.  Fruity and caramel.  Somewhat of an iced tea body.  Syrupy and caramel sweet.  Nice yeasty flavor.  Dry and full finish.  Quality.

Amber orange body with a small head. Aroma is earth and English hops, only a hint of their yeast. The flavor has more of the Pacman yeast taste in it. Some caramel in there, obviously bitter finish. Didnt like it as much as so many other Rogues out there.
Pours amber with a minimal white head.  Aroma is full of hops and some caramel malt.  Taste is hops and citrus with a sweet malt backing.  Another great beer from Rogue.

Pour is a amber with a small white head.  Aroma is very much in the hop and citrus catagory.  Flavor is also hoppy with a bit of citrus showing up. Pretty tasty with the hops not making an overpowering taste like most Rouge beer.
Bottle. Pour was amber, tah head. Nose had citrus and grapefruit hops. Taste also had malt backbone. Balanced body, smooth, good brew.

Bottled, pasteurised, 650ml. Clear redish amber colour with good bubbly head. I wasnt expecting much from this, after all I live in the land of Bitter and this is an interloper, like selling ice to eskimos, but it really is a well crafted bottled Premium (or best) bitter. Light fragrant hops to the fore, lasting and citrusy, a pleasant light bitter malt background with hints of caramel. One of the better bottled bitters I have had, very nice.

12 oz bottle-pours a tan, creamy, rocky head.  Color is hazy copper with a few tiny particles.  Aroma is hops, citrus.  Taste is hops, citrus, then malt comes through in the background nicely.  Mild carbonation.

One pint, six ounce brown bottle purchased from Armanettis, Mundelein, IL. Clear amber ale having a small diminishing head with good lacing.  Nice toffee and sweet malt aroma. Soft carbonation. Medium bodied that starts with light sweet malt and hop flavors.  Middles with light bitterness. Finishes with light nutty malt flavor and lingering bitterness.  Well-balanced, this is a good drinkable beer that goes well with food.

Bottle shared with tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a cloudy dark orange with a small white head. Aroma has a strange hoppy smell -- it smelt like a grilled cheese sandwich to me! Flavour of hops, tea and yes -- grilled cheese. Such a strange beer, I really liked it.
Pours a nice reddish orange color. Aromas of nice citrus/grapefruit hops and sweet malts.  Flavor starts nice crisp bitter hop and then mellows to a nice malt..

Bottle. Id seen this in Sainsburys quite a few times and didnt bother to buy it, it was fairly expensive and I hadnt been that keen on some of the other Rogues Id tried. Then I saw it reduced and thought well its now or never and Im quite glad I got it. Citrus hops up front leading into a more piney earthy type bitterness in the body. Some of the malty yeast type flavours I havent been to impressed with in other Rogues but not on the same scale. I was quite suprised to see that the hops were Willamete (US fuggles?) and EKG as this seemed like US hops all the way.

Bottle from the Rogue pub in San Francisco shared with Blankboy.  Nice deep sweet caramel malt and hop aroma.  Deep dark orange, small off white head.  Nice orange citrus and malt taste.  There was an interesting tea like / maybe even grilled cheese quality to it as well.  Certainly the mix of hops is interesting here.  A solid representation of the ESB style here.
Red amber in appearence with small  off white head.  Lacing is visible.  Smooth but dies of with a bitter aftertaste.  For sure has the normal rouge taste.  Malty but still light with hops Good Beer.
650ml bottle from sainsburys. Amber colour. Lovely hop flavours. I really liked this one.

Hazy light amber colour.  Light spicy/citrusy hop aroma, UK-style malts.  Flavour is well-balanced, sweetness up front, a bit herbal and woodsy.  Clean finish with light earthy bitterness.  Well-balanced tasty brew.

The brutal bitter impressed me a bit by not being aggressively overhopped like the old crusty, and this beer, too, showed remarkable restraint in the hop department.  The malt profile was a little weaker than in the brutal bitter, however, somewhat more muddled and with less biscuit and more diacetyl touches.  Oh well.  Not a bad little beer.

A Mes rate: 
Mmm quite tasty this one. The aroma has a touch of the Abbaye des Rocs. Very hoppy with a touch of orange and spice in there. Appearance is a cloudy amber and quite unusual. Head is fairly decent and lasts reasonably well. Nice creamy body, plenty of hops and more cream but not sweet. Palate is pretty damn good. As ESBs go in my experience this is a pretty good one. Considering they have this cheap at Sainsbury then I would expect to have a few more of these in the future

18-Oct-05 (22 oz bottles: $4 at Issaquah Brewery in Issaquah, WA) While visiting breweries all around the Pacific Northwest, I found bottles of Fat Heads Ale and Cliff Hanger Ale at the Issaquah Brewery, and since I collect bottles, I figured Id get these beers for my collection, even if they are the same beer as the Youngers Special Bitter.  I suspect my review of Youngers from 16 months ago is a bit off, which is part of the reason why Im doing a new rating here.  Even though Im not directly comparing them with the Youngers, I can definitely confirm that Fat Head and Cliff Hanger taste exactly the same.  Theyre mildly fruity, lightly sweet and toasty, and gently bitter though the bitterness tends to be the slightly dominant aspect.  Theres also a mild tartness in the background.  The nose is fairly toasty and dry, with a grassy aroma.  Medium bodied, and the carbonation levels are about average for beer.  Hazy, dark amber in color.  The off-white head pours pretty tall, and retention is solid, holding a thin layer for the entire session, although the Cliff Hanger is holding a good quarter-inch or more, and the lacing for that beer is wonderfully ringed.  Overall, this isnt bad, but still pretty mediocre by Rogue standards, and far from being one of my favorites.16-Jun-04 (22 oz bottle: Whole Foods in San Diego/Hillcrest) Like the Fullers ESB, the nose is woody and malty, and the flavor is fairly malty and fairly sweet, but that is where the similarities end.  The key difference is that this medium bodied ESB has the classic strong hops bitterness toward the finish that is typical of Rogue beers, and it tends to overpower the malt at that point.  The flavor also lacks any fruitiness.  There is also a fair amount of hoppiness in the nose.  Bright amber color.  Off-white head has excellent retention, but leaves only a modest amount of lacing.

Picked up one of these in the discount singles bin at Sams Quickshop.  This is probably the best beer Ive found in the discount bin there before.  Generally I prefer IPAs to ESBs, but this beer definitely held its own.  Deep honey color, kind of opaque, not a whole lot of bubbles, but a creamy off-white head.  Aroma is sweet (toffee, some fruit).  Flavor starts sweet, malty, and ends up with a pleasant, medium-to-high bitter.  The hops dont really stick around long though.  There is a bit of a metallic ness to the bitter unfortunately, and the palatte is a bit on the watery side.

Redish gold pour, fluffy head that disapears. Good lacing, ok whiff, nutty. A well balanced Rogue, not their best.
Nutmeggy aftertaste.

22 oz. bottle.  Different label than that in the picture.  Pours a hazy iced-tea brown with a thin light-tan head.  Nicely balanced aroma with a moderate amount of piney hops and caramelly malts.  Pretty earthy.  Medium body.  Mild amount of both hops and malts in the taste.  A little caramel, sap and alcohol.  A sour, bitter finish.  Nothing special.

bottled as summits wayside cliff hanger ale.  fragrant signature rogue hop aroma with some sweet toffee.  more noticeable malts in this beer.  same rogue hop character but less boldness.  cloudy amber color.  somewhat thin and smooth.

Red brown. Nice foamy head
leaving lacings as you drink. Flowers and citrus from the hops in the
nose. Rather mild bitterness with a reasonable maltiness and
pronounced flowery taste with some grapefruit.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours cloudy dark amber color with thin off white head.  Decent  lacing as I drank.  Kind of a tart aroma, reminds me of chewable vitamin C I used to eat as a kid.  Very mild Bitter tastewise.  I can drink this on a nice hot day.  Very mild hop taste, decent malt body.  Thin on the palate.  No aftertaste.  I like Brutal better.
Mildly spicy and citrus hop aroma. Cloudy amber with a thumb thick head. Easy drinking ale with a mild hop presence medium malt body and somewhat thin palate. Decent enough.
Great colour.  Nce amount of hops. Thought I tasted a hint of citrus.  Foamy head.

Pours hazy dark orange with a foamy off-white head. Creamy and malty aroma with some spicy hints and orange notes - nice and balanced. Malt and hop flavor with a dry and dusty edge. Pretty light in the taste and a bit thin, but easy drinkable. Hmmm.....
An orange beer with a thin beige head. The aroma is OK hoppy, while the flavor is dry hoppy, and the body is thin. OK, but I had expected more, so Im somewhat disappointed.
Bottle. Dark amber colour with a off-white head. Malty light hoppy aroma and a dry hoppy light bitter taste. Medium body and a dry finish.

Bottled: Light amber coloured. Unclear. Beige head. Has this spruce needle aroma you find in many of these hoppy american beers. Not that it by any meens is unpleasent, but beers tend to be very similar. Oh well. Herbs, some fruity and loads of malts in the aroma. Flavour is herbal and malty with some vague choco notes. Is light fruity with a bitter touch in the end.

Cloudy amber color with off-white head. Aroma dominated by malts. So is the taste. Hops jump in behind the malt to bitter-up the flavor, though the bitterness doesnt linger long. Leans toward the sweet side, but avoids a syrupy mouthfeel. Medium to thin body, clean sipping. A nice, refreshing bitter.

Bottled. RBESG -05. 
Amber colour. Rich hop aroma and flavour, though not on the citrusy side. Dry mouthfeel.

Bottled at RBESG 2005.
Cloudy orange coloured with a yellow head.
Aroma of malts and caramel.
Flavour of fruits, caramel and hops.

Amber coloured with a thick white head.
Hoppy, flowery orange nose with a small alcoholic hint. Dry mouthfeel.
Sweet, refreshing hoppy flavour. Slight fruity. Flavour fades away quickly though.....too bad, since it´s wonderful.
Great bitter finish.

Bottle 12 oz. Brown color with full off-white head that diminished slowly. Roasted malt aroma. Medium body. Well balanced malt flavor with a medium pleasing bitter finish. Very enjoyable drinkable brew.

I liked everything about this beer: the bottle, the logo, the name - to say nothing of the attractive amber colour and frothy off-white head and lacing, the glorious floral aroma, the malty taste with citrus and other fruits and the satisfying bitter finish. Class act.

This is a fine beer.   Deep amber wirh a full, frothy, off white head with a load of lace.  A toasted aroma with a hint of sourwood honey.  Taste includes some pine and grapefruit.  Malty sweet, but balanced by lingering bitterness.   fine

This is a pleasant ESB, not as strong as the Brutal Bitter. Appearance is brown with a nice, thick head. Nice mild bitter with a taste that is dominated by malt flavors. Easy to drink, makes for a decent session beer.
Orange/copper with a fluffy off-white head leaving lots of lacing on the glass.  Orange, lemon and malt flavours with a nice clean finish.  Flavours could be a bit stronger, but still a good product.

Amber with thin off-white head.  Flowery hop aroma with some slight bready yeast notes.  Taste is cookie with resinous hops. Not enough maltiness to balance the bitter.  Not exceptional or special, but good nonetheless.

Bottled. Warm brown body, thin head, steady carbonation. Great bready nose, hopped softly with floral notes, good malty backwash. Hope Sainsburys start selling this off cheap so I can buy up a crateload!

Amber in colour with medium carbonation. Loads of great aromas with this one: beginning with citrus and bready malts, then evolving into black licorice and flowers. The flavors arent quite as complex, but strike a good balance between malt and bitterness. An average Rogue beer, which is still pretty good in my books.
Slightly cloudy amber color with a thin head. Just the right amount of hop flavor and a great aftertaste. A nice beer.

Was expecting a bitter beer face with this one. I was wrong. Aroma had a sweet citrus to it. Body was darker shade of orange. Tan decent head. Decent hop flavor and was quite refreshing on the palate seeing its 110 today. Good Beer.
[bottle from sainburys] pours amber with a fluffy head. nose is citrus with strong undertows of biscuity malts. body is light with a lightly bitter finish

650 ml bottle.  Recommended to me by a friend so I was expecting it to be better than it was.  Russet in colour, slightly cloudy, good goldings nose, slightly biscuity with the yeast.  Good acidic citric finish and even slightly metallic.  Fine but no great shakes
A careml/orange beer with a short off white head and an aroma of foral and citrus. Pretty light, good for late night summer drinking. Tastes of hops, and honey with a bitter metallic finish.

650 ml bottle. Hazy orange amber colour with a mostly diminishing frothy off-white head. Caramel, bready, grapefruit, and lightly floral aroma. Toasty and carmel flavours with a grapefruit and light piny bitter finish. Light bodied but refreshing.

Bottled.  A reddy brown coloured beer with a wispish white head.  The aroma is fruity with blackberries noted.  It is also nicely hoppy and there are perfume notes.  The taste is hoppy and fruity with some strawberry.  A very nice tasty beer
Very good bitter..  I do like ESBs and will try this one again.  Available in my area and I will consume more of..
Bottled.  Vibrant dark brown beer with a strong head.  The aroma is sweet, very fruity and quite dry, the flavour is very hopped and dry with a very long finish.  Overall a good deeply dry beer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2005 Great nose on this mild offer from Rogue. Yeasty apple cider look. Nose of butterscotch and roses. Very nutty and flowery taste with excellent finish. Not really that heavily hopped. This was right up my ally and I wish I had a sixer. I absolutely loved this offering. I normally do not like beer with a sour tinge , but this beer is the exception with its citrus hints.The ultimate late summer night BBQ brew. 

12/20/05 rerate.....bought an old six pack from my local shitty party store....a real old six pack....this is unfair, but the old beer is going to force me to lower the score....

will need to find fresh again and rerate...

Bottle. Pous light red with foamy white head that dissipates quickly leaving some lacing and a thin layer of head reminents. Nose is sweet and fruity, some sort of berry I couldnt put my finger on. Mouth is light water, small amoount of hops with a strong bitter finish.

Very hoppy/IPA type smell.  Not particularly bitter but with a nice blend of hops.  Unfortunately it has almost a honey flavoring to it, which, in my opinion is the worst thing you can add to a beer unless youre attempting to make mead.  Otherwise, very nice.

The aroma smells of oranges, caramel, and bread.  The head is a root beer float type off-white frothy rocky head.  So-so lacing atop a VERY bubbly semi-opaque deep orange body.  The flavor is malty and has a lightly bitter taste of spruce.  Unfortunately, the palate is super slick.  I can hardly tell its in my mouth.  There is a ton of carbonation.  Too much so.  Theres just so much missing from this beer.

Bottle from Goldtwins branded as Summits Wayside Cliff Hanger ale.  Pours out a beautiful orange amber color and is just a little opaque.  A compact off-white head forms and never fully dissipates.  Very nice lacing.   The aroma is very rich, smelling like molasses and caramel.  Medium bodied with pleasant carbonation.  Nicely malted flavor, again molasses seems to dominate.  There is a fair amount of hops that come across as earthy and a bit floral in the finish.  A little bit drying.  Overall a very nice ESB, could use a little more hop aroma perhaps.
Dark amber coloed with a loose head.  Has a strange  wet cardboard aroma, very little malt flavor, and almost no hops bitterness.  Not a strong offering from Rogue.

Amber with a short white head that dissipates surprisingly quick.  Aroma is of yeast and light hops.  Flavor is earthy and sweet to start with and finishes somewhat bitter yet with a good sweet aftertaste.  A good bitter.  I havent had a bad brew from Rogue yet.  Tasty and a good session beer.
Bottle from Sainsburys. Sickly, hoppy, yeasty and sweet beer that starts off nicely but ends in a horrible mismash of flavours that dont belong. Has nothing on a cask bitter.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Good on them. Im assuming this is meant to be like Youngs Special rather than (remember this?) S&Ns Youngers Special (shudder...). It is a bit like Youngs on a good day, copper colour, hops a little more noticeable in the aroma, and still manages to smell American if that makes any sense. Good body and finishes well with a smoky, earthy note as well as the hoppy tang.

Bottle from Sainsburys.  Amber with a small white head.  Aromas are sweet pine hops and citrus, quite dry and "USA hopping"-like in its character.  Flavours are sweet citrus followed by woody, nutty flavours.  Some sweet pine with a dry earthy finish.  A very nice beer.  Remember, the more premium overseas beers beers we buy from Sainsburys the more beers they will stock.

Bottle from Sainsburys, Selly Oak, Birmingham. Smells precisely as it should - like a UK Bitter, fused with US hops. A little bit of plastic malt in the flavour - dragging in the finish. Has some fresh hop, but its a background thing. Fairly refreshing, but has an artificial edge.
Pours light copper with a lasting white head. Mild earthy hop aroma, with some citric and woody notes. Delicate malt flavours balanced perfectly with a nice hoppy finish. Very nice bitter.
Good for the style.  Unfortunately I find it a bit underhopped -- I was hoping for a more American style ESB.  My standards for bitterness are just too inflated for the British.
Golden coloured bitter with slight citrus flavours. Easy to drink, quite gentle and pleasant.

From A Bottle.Amber brown in colour with a small lasting head,aroma is of light malt,
taste is of light sweet malt and hops,and a light bitter finish.
pretty amber color with thich head.  bitter, hoppy flavor.  slighty sweet finish, but that didnt seem to detract that much.
Great new favorite session beer...fruity finish that I didnt expect.  All in all a very well-done bitter.

This does a handsome pour, clear amber in color with a rocky white head.  The aroma is malty with apples and pears and a balancing herbal hopping.  Very smooth in the mouth and all the way down the throat, the flavor reflects the aroma, leaving a light herbal, bitter finish.  Nice drink.

Youngers Special Bitter is a decent ale. Ive only experienced its lucious flavors once, but it was a real enjoyment when I did. I found a love for its light amber colour, toasty malts, and slight bitterness!
Pretty good. had a really sweet taste. kind of like strawberry candy.  kinda bitter. not too bad.
Light amber in color with a small white head. Sweet toasted malt aroma. Flavor is bitter,hoppy with a dry finish.
Red-amber.   Nice fruit and hop smell.  Floral hops like an IPA but does have a nice malt touch but not alot of complexity in flavor.  Slight peach hints.  Bitter end.

12oz bottle from the fridge. It was WAY too cold at 31°, so I poured it and let it sit in the Duvel tulip for a while. It poured orange/red with a 1/2" off white head. No sedimentation apparent. Now at 44°, Ill give it a taste. Honey malt nose with some hops notes. Smells good. Taste is caramel malts with some light floral hops, maybe a touch of apricot,  and a mild bitterness. The finish is dry, with some more bitterness coming through. The body is full. I find this very enjoyable, it would make a good session beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small white head.  Aroma of maple syrup, waffles, and brown sugar.  Flavor of rich malt and caramel.

Caramel colored with tinges of yellow, nice lingering head.  Standard bitter/sour aroma.  Understated fruity sweetness from the hops becomes more prevalent in the transition to the finish.  Fairly thin body, with perhaps not enough malt character to balance the hops, in both flavor and aroma.  The greatest atribute of this beer I believe to be the finish, rather crisp and adding greatly to this beers drinkability.  A rather stunted bitter, it lacks the synergy of bitterness and sweetness necessary to stand out in this style.

Bottle.  This one pours a dark amber with little head.  A little bit of hop in the nose, but not really much aroma wafting up from this one.  Lets begin... Ok, first we get some malt... a little like an English pale ale with Kent Goldings, but they taste more like Fuggles.  Not overwhelming, but an Ok brew.  No real sweet maltiness to match the bitter.  Not very balanced.  Too much sour and bitter.  Overrated, probably because it has the Rogue name on it.  Worst one Ive had from them, but still not terrible.

Pours copper with a average white head that  lasts a while.  Good lacing.  Aromas of pine and apple with some caramel malt (not much).  Flavor is initally acidic.  It finishes moderately bitter finish.  I may be strange, but I tasted raisin and pineapple.  Medium-full body with soft carbonation and a lightly metallic finish.

Fairly basic bitter, less malt forward caramel and crytal than I would expect. Very soft and unassuming mouthfeel. mild East kent bittering with some minor hop pellet astringency. Overall too lite for style with a very soft finish.
This is a great beer. Mild bitterness makes this one that anyone could enjoy. The copper coloring looks great and inviting inthe glass. Definately one to be shared with friends.

thick, spicy, and prickly. watery, spicy, and bitter. slightly sweet, fruity. clean, but not aspiring. floral. dry, slight pine. i think i may have sampled this at an inappropriate time--just not sure about this.
strong aroma that is like iced tea with some maple. pours slight orange brown. smooth bitter flavor. notes of caramel. very drinkable would make a nice session beer.
Bottle. Very floral nose. Good med-low bitterness with alot of straw and hay notes. Not bad.

The bottle poured a slightly cloudy reddish-copper liquid. The head was white creamy and of medium size. It lasted very long leaving very nice lacing. The aroma was malty with hints of grass. The initial flavor was of malt sweetness. Hop bitterness dominated the middle and the finish is strong and long-lasting, and still mostly made up of hop bitterness.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2005 Pous a hazy amber with a nice offwhite head.  The nose is a superb, slightly musky caramel.  The mouthfeel is very good - along the lines of the Dead Guy.  The bitter in the end is a bit more lengthy, and the camel comes through a bit more.  Plumbs and citrus dominate the palate.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dense dark golden amber with a tight beige head.  Aroma is primarily floral with notes of spices and grapefruit.  Well-balanced, but it leans more towards the hoppy side, which I prefer for an ESB.  Good lacing.  Always a staple Rogue beer.

For some reason Rogue is one of the brewerys I take for granted, esp when it come to their 6-pack selection, and I am always reminded how good the beer is when go back and try it.  This ESB is a prime example.  Slightly hazy amber with a huge initial head (at least in my alt glass) that almost reminds me of a root-beer float, nonending.  Seductive floral-citrus aroma.  A nice balance of orange hop and pale malt taste.  A very pleasant beer.

Pours cloudy amber with a really nice well retained off white colored head.  Aroma is hoppy a bit floral and spicy.  Flavor is mildy biscuity on the front then a bit of spicy hops kick in the finish.  Another Rogue winner.
Nice rocky head, moderate lacing. Citrus, orange peel, toffee, and flowery hop aromas. Medium weight, nice dry finish

Poured a nice red amber with a smallish head but thick lacing.
Aroma of hops and citrus.
Flavor of hops, malt, and citrus.
Nice easy drinking hopy beer.
Not bad at all.

Golden pour, creamy ivory head - strong aroma of sweet malts, fresh bread.  Smooth mouthfeel but a bit thin in the middle.  The malts are light and a bit sour.  Orange/lemon aftertaste.  Good drinkability.
On tap @ Rogue Pub SF.  Hazey dark yellow/ orange  color.  A bit of a hop nose.  Flavor was that of butter and oranges.  Overall , its too watery.

Pours clear copper amber with nice beige head (different experience than gentleman below). Mild large-chunk lacing.  Somewhat soapy cask flavor on vehicle of (willamette?) hops and clean, substantial mouthfeel.  Finish is a touch metallic, but overall great for a one-of beer or for a session.

Pours a darker amber that is fairly cloudy, low carbonation.  Nose is vegetal with some hops, fairly clean.  Has more of an astringent taste that most of the ESBs Ive tried, although the mildly bitter hops character is present.  Creamy malt notes are noticably absent.  Fairly watery mouthfeel and mild bitter aftertaste.  OK but not the best.

Somewhat of a hoppy aroma.  Orange hue with some small flakes floating around.  A small amount of hops are also present in the flavor and a malt background. I must say this is a very flavorful premium bitter compared to the rest.  A little dry and a medium flow of carbonation leaves me satisfied with this ESB.

2004 bottle.  Pours brownish amber with decent head that disperses quickly with white foam that laces the glass.  Aroma is fruity and spicey with a tempting alure.  Taste is alittle disappointing with the major taste being of watery hops.  I do like the lightness and drinkablity of the beer.  Seems to be a overload of flour and wheat present in the flavor.  Still a decent drinking beer and is crisp and fresh.  This beer would go well before dinner as an apertif.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Pours a deep amber with no head.  Malty aroma, but very lite and non-descript.  Flavor has toasted malts and faint sweetness.  Lite piney hops from the middle to the end.  Very straight forward.  The body is lighter than I would like but acceptable.   Easy to drink.  Session like. 
HA HA HA, Rogue you dogs you go t me to rerate your beer again by putting it in a different bottle.  How rogueish of you. No change in score though.
Hazy reddish-orange with a creamy head. Aromas of sweet malts with fruity undertones. Caramel flavors give way to piney hops, leading to a sour middle with tastes of grapefruit. Long bitter finish.

MIld fruity/citrus hop aroma with a hint of malt.  Light amber color with a slight haze.  Medium to moderate hop bitterness that increases as beer warms, balanced by a hint of maltiness.  No appreciable lingering bitterness.  Light body, a little lighter than would be expected.

Poured a hazy copper color with a medium sized, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of sweet malts, citrus, and floral hops.  Subdued taste, malt sweetness, nice hoppy, bitter finish.  Inferior to the Brutal Bitter, IMO.

Bottle.  Floral candy-like citrus aroma.  Very sweet in the nose.  Kind of reminds me of their Brutal Bitter.  Mild to moderate haziness copperish colored with light tan head.  Lots of nice maltiness in the middle with plenty of caramel flavors.  Finishes mildly hoppy and bitter with a trace of that candy sweetness.  Quality.

hazy apricot color supporting a decent and active head with moderate lacing.  Very appetizing aroma of hops and fruit but the fruity notes were not sweet or overpowering.  Crisp hoppy flavor with just a touch of spiciness and a ripple of sweetness with citrus zest.  Pleasant bitter finish that was as dry as sandpaper.  Dont know why I waited so long to try this.

This bottled brew poured a unnoted head size of foamy fine to medium sized light brown colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body contained soft carbonation, was transparent and light brown in color with swirls of brown malts and yest.  Its aroma contained notes of butter malty hoppy.  Its mouth feel is initially tingly bitter hoppy with a  palate and a aftertaste.  Its flavor contained dark beer brown malts  notes and was very tasty.  All-in-all very nice brew.
bottle. nice orange color, large fluffy head laced very well. the most delicately malted rogue beer ive tasted thus far but with enough nice hops to finish well.
Pours a hazy orange brown, nice white bubbly head. Aroma of grapefruit, apples and hay. Flavor is sublte, of apples and bitter floral hops. Palate is smooth, and full.

Mild, pleasant grapefruit hop nose.  Clear copper-orange with decent tan head that recedes to cover with some lace.  Decent bitterness and floral hop flavour.Medium-light body and refreshing effervescence.  Bottle enjoyed with Enkerli and others.
Pours light brown with a small white head. Hop aroma. Earthy hop taste. Simple good tasting, hoppy, average malt. Well done. Good session beer.
Aroma is a balance of caramely malt and a hint of hops.  Caramel flavour well balance with hops bitterness.  Alcohol warmth on palate with medium body.
Amber in color with a large beige creamy head. Aroma is hoppy, floral and caramel. Flavor is balanced well, slightly sweet. Finsh is bitter
and yet another tasty treat from the rogue fellas.   not the best ESB I have ever had, but not a bad example  (the brutal bitter is more to my liking)
Refreshing balanced malt hop aroma, light amber orange color, mildly sugar sweet amlt taste which fades quickly. A good beer to wean someone off macros

Bottle. Medium size off-white head, minimal lacing, transparent, carbonated, and an orange hue. Malty, some caramel, hoppy, and grapefruit aroma. Sweet, acidic, bitter, malty, and hoppy flavor. Tingly mouthfeel. Quite drinkable.

A nice brown brew with apple sauce head. The aroma is floral, brown sugar and apple. Essentially no sweetness. Dull hops. Smells bitter but not so in the taste. Like a cross between a brown ale and an APA. Great aroma, else flacid.

Amber with a frothy white head.  Aroma is a lively, slightly citrusy hoppiness.  Very nice hop-dominated flavor, fruity and fairly bitter, but well balanced by the malts.  Much like a mild IPA to my senses.  This is a really nice beer: easy to drink, yet full of stimulating hop flavors.  Another excellent Rogue.

Nice hoppy aroma with hints of pepper, malt and ripened fruit.  Body is amber with thin white head.  Very nice and fruity, this is the first bitter that Ive had that I can say is a very good beer.  Wonderful.
UPDATED: APR 29, 2005 An excellent, if not too exotic bitter. Amber color, citric hop aroma.  Smooth taste with noticeable, but not too overpowering caramel taste. Nicely balanced texture.

Light amber color with almost no head.  Decent aroma of goldings hops, and some fruitiness from the yeast.  Good malty flavor with an ok balance but a little on the light side.    Doesnt compare to some real english styles like fullers.
Great amber color. Medium body. Very drinkable, with moderate hops and not overpowering malt. Great for parties and other events, such as mowing lawns.
Pours deep clear gold with a thin white head. Toffee/butterscotch aroma. Bitter, salty, citric hop. Malty and lots of caramel. Good but plain.
on tap in newport. golden, served a bit too cold. quite a sweet lemonade and grapefruit aroma. reasonable bitterness, perhaps a bit lacking in body

This is a pretty decent American Bitter.  Certainly better than what some others are offering.  There is a nice malt aroma with a near perfect balance of hops.  However, I think that there is a little too much reliance upon [dark] crystal malts to give the malt aroma and less on just adjusting the mash temperature for a more dextrinous beer.  In short, this beer could stand just a little less caramel.
I havent had a bad Rogue yet.  Nice Bitter, could feel it on the tounge.  Good for these autumn nights
Good! Nice strong hop flavor. Green, some mild citrus hop aroma.  Thin mouth feel made a little thicker by carbonation.  Easy to drink but heavy enough to be satisfying.
Pours a cloudy golden color.  Smells of a very nice blend of hops.   Tastes very thin but hoppy, interesting malt character - very nice ESB.

Hazy Orange

Sticky, elaborate and earthy aroma. Scents of fruit punch, butter and grapefruit mingle around while a constant flow of burnt caramel malt tries to take over the show.

Great example of its style. Consistently balanced. Front is an herbal fruitiness with notes of grapefruit and melon. Mid is dry and maintains the fruitiness, this time in a ripe fashion. Finish is moderately hoppy and mainly dominated by caramel.
An excellent ESB - one of the best that Ive tried. Still havent had a bad Rogue brew.

I drank this as Summits Wayside Tavern in a 22 oz bomber I picked up as a souvenier from my GA trip. Now this is an awesome ESB. Isnt the first beer you drink when yoou get off of work just great? Clean, crisp and smooth. I typically hate ESBs but I love the hop mix in this. Easy drinking and creamy. The balance is remarkable.
Bottle - nice grassy hop nose.  Beautiful copper/amber color with about a two-fingered beige head.  Mild hop bitterness with a nice malt backbone.  This is a classy bitter.

Wonderful, clean aroma. Flavor is a masterful blend of hops and malt seldom found in such balanced proportion even in the Old World. Very subtantial bodied beer. Who could imagine beer this great coming out of not California - not Washington - but s**t sandwich Oregon! Highly recommended!
Deep orange with thin beige head. Nice hoppy aroma of apricots- very clean.  Nice fresh hop flavor very full mouthfeel.  Malt balances extremely well with the hops. Very well made beer.
Definitely Rogue, but a little lighter than other offerings.  Also, hop/malt flavor seemed unique, even for Rogue.  Nice bitters, good feel & finish.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Hazy, light copper appearance with good lacing.  Got more maltiness in  the aroma than in the taste.  Medium-bodied flavor was well hopped and decently balanced.  Long, dry, bitter finish.   Reminded me somewhat of an amber ale.

Pours a dark amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malty and floral. Taste is moderately sweet and earthy with caramel malt, citrus/light fruits and mild hops. Bitter finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Good head retention and lacing. A quality brew.
Had it on cask at Fat Heads in Pittsburgh.  Very pleasurable and easy drinking bitter.  A bit hoppy but not unpleasantly so.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2004 Bottled.  Good sized, off white head with and orange hue and numerous speckles and sheets of lacing, fully lasting head.  Liquid is clear, amber with a little red added.  The nose revealed is sweetly malty, with mostly caramel, some sugar, some dough like yeast, soil and musk, some fruit like peach.  Lively, lasting carbonation, medium body, watery finish, dry later.  Sugary sweet front followed by peachish hops with no sweet of itself, but underlying front is still with and that is maintained throughout.  Some grapefruit rind, light caramel.  The palate near perfect  Well designed beer that I keep coming back to.

hoppy aromas with a subdued matly cookie smell.  hazy amber color with an off white head.  sweet flavors of malt, caromel, bread and cookies. hop flavors emerge toward the finish. enough bitterness to balance the sweet malt. some american hop grapefruit flavors.  a tastey beer. a little more complex than you run of the mill ESB, but not as complex as some british varieties. the american hops are prevalent and less subtle than british types.

Bottle Pours a fairly dark amber/copper with a slight head and decent lacing.  Aroma is a dark malt with some hops but not overpowering . Flavor is malty and hoppy, but lacking the harsh bitterness.  Smooth and nice and heavy. Missing that lingering bitterness, or most of it. A very drinkable "Bitter"

Amber color with a rather large white head. Light hop aroma with hints of malt and citrus. Mildly hoppy flavor with a nice malt balance. Kind of reserved for
a Rogue. Very easy drinking.

Amber in color, very crisp & smooth body, very drinkable, huge bubbly & fluffy white head, great lacing around the glass, big malty nose with a prominent aroma of fruit, great hoppy flavors with more fruity notes, creamy body, great session beer, smooth finish with malty notes, nice bitter

Clear amber brown, with fine thick head. Some floral hops, with malt aromas. Hoppy start and finsh with crisp fruit, becoming almost creamyas it warms. Very refreshing. Great session beer...Dont you just love Rogue?!!
amber body light large frothy head head, looks very appetising. full smelling  very very smooth. a little bitter in the 1st taste and the after taste. yet not to over powering
Poured a medium amber color with a very small head. Musty smelling with light hoppy citris. Light bitter taste with slight spice. Watery body. This was OK but to me, nothing too special.

Im a big fan of Rogue and the bar I had this one at, didnt know what they had.  I got them for under 2 bucks a bottle!  Nice bitter, great coloring and head.  If you like a good bitter style, go out and give this one a try!

Decnt head form the pour.  White to off-white.  Nice lacing.  Good aroma with a hefty helping of hops and a good malt backbone to offset it.  A little pine also.  Medium copper in color.  Decent flavor but not that strong.  More hops and bitterness.  Hint of caramel.  Finish is clean and slightly bitter.  A very good bitter.

Clear orange/amber, pinky high ivory cap, becomes fluffy and crusty looking as it slowly dwindles down to a thin haze on top and a thin collar. Lace in minimal strings. Aroma reminds me of a very subdued barleywine-esk nose, some caramel, a bit toasty, slight pine sap, sweet malt mostly, dry hop leaves and floralness touch the back end in bigger wiffs. Taste is nice and mild, welcoming warm toasty malts favor from front to back. Some refined and soft malt sweetness of breads and dull fruit keep it smooth and tolerable to the palate. Theres a nice subtlety about its approach. Floating and caring malt character with the same amount of comfort with the hop profile which has very slight floral, citrus, and pine mindfully placed in different areas throughout the palate. Feel is light and fluffy with a firm and sturdy, smoother lighter body. Which seems to fit this here, making for a nice little drinker. This is one of the few 12oz bottles with a paper label that Rogue distributes, which is a bit weird, cuz I really like seeing the ingredients listed like on their bombers. Oh well...label, no label, this is a pretty nice beer.

Pours copper with a nice eggshell head and lace.  Aroma of hops, malt, fruit, pine.  Tastes very bitter, not much sweetness at all in this one, with hop, slight fruit, chardonnay, pine, and cognac taste overtones.  Finishes very dry, bitter, and piney.  It got creamier as it warmed.
