Quite nice. Citric floral hops, lightl bready, extremely soft malts. Would have been even better if the mouthfeel had a bit of a kick to it, really soft, and ironed out mouthfeel. A good session beer.

Pours a light amber with a thick off-white head. Mild hop nose, with faint malt undertones. Thin mouthfeel. Mild sweet and fruity taste. Dry finish with a long and lingering aftertaste. A good bitter, still rather weak on flavor. But for a bitter it was very good.

Hopy aroma but beyond that you shall find sweet malty notes . Dull amber look with presentable lace . Medium bodies, quiet bitter as it should be. Fun to drink, very refreshing ale. Simple made but that just works fine with me.

Clear amber. Beige head w/ inconsistent beading. Aroma of caramel, citrus, & minty  hops. Medium, lightly resiny feel. Strong, moderately sweet malt character gives way to an dry, earthy, bitter finish w/ some lingering fruity traces of grapefruit.
Bottled as Cliff Hanger. Dark amber with a nice beige head. Sweet hoppiness with caramel and a hint of fruit. Finish is highly assertive.

Pours a dark amber body with a thin light brown head. Aromas are fairly robust with a combination of candy hoppiness and some malt. Taste is bitter hops, mingled with some breadiness. Nice mouthfeel with a great bitter aftertaste. Rogue continues to suprise me.

Rich, sweet, hoppy nectar aroma. Beautiful deep orange/amber, with a murky body and lots of carbonation. Slightly off-white head that is reasonably lasting and wonderful lace. Nice and hoppy initial mouthfeel. Wonderful, doughy finish. Perhaps not sweet enough to be truly fine. Wonderful mouth feel, and a nice, long, pine-hop finish that is not harshly hoppy. For a brewer that makes such great painted label bottles, their paper label on this one is quite attractive. I could polish off a few of these in a sitting. Perhaps a little too hoppy to be a session brew, but it comes about as close as you could expect for a beer with this many IBUs.
Golden Amber color, lasting head.  Long lingering bitterness, but not overly bitter.  Medium-light mouthfeel.

Pours a foggy bronze with a thin but lasting head. Smells like a bitter, very nicely done hops and honey. Taste is certainly bitter but not overly so. Feels a little weak though, doesnt possess that full robustness of other bitters. Overall a great bitter.
Bomber labeled as Cliff Hanger, and thanks to BeerCellar2 for the hookup. A beer that lives up to its billing.  It is what it says it is. My first Rogue brew, and Im impressed.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 A nice product for Rogue. I need to get around to rerating some time. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a golden brown with a medium tan head. There is a flowery, hoppy aroma. The flavor is strongly bitter, hoppy and a little fruity on the aftertaste.

Bottle, no expiration date.  Pours dark amber with huge head.  Slight chill haze.  Aroma is surprisingly light with hops predominating.  Taste is a symphony of malt, toffee and non-cascade hops.  This is really a great Brit style session bitter.  Not so bitter your taste buds are toast after a couple of pints and interesting enough to drink a lot of.  Id love to get this locally on tap but then again its so tasty I'd need to get a designated driver.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2005 appearance has a great amber color with a nice white head that drops fast. Aroma has a great hop smell with some malt to go with it. Taste is initially sweet than the hops kick in and bitter it down. Rogue makes some amazing beers.
Great hops!Good taste top to bottom.I believe this beer is better than its 80 oveall percentile

Cask, NERAX festival, Somerville, MA. Good nose, Carmel peach/apricot. Hazy brownish orange. Sweet and bitter. Orange, grapefruit, tea. Thin, litely oily, bitter fruity finish. Nice, easy drinking bitter
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: A very serviceable and competent ESB reminiscent of an IPA.  Pours a clear copper color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of crackers and wet hay.  Flavor nicely balances piney and grassy hops with toasty, crackery malt.  A hint of lemon is also present.  Nice, tight carbonation enhances mouthfeel.  Good beer.

This beer looks beautiful. It has hints of pine in the nose. This is a beer that I would rather look at than drink. It is  simply too bitter for me. But if you like bitter beer you will love this bitter beer.
Amber woth a hint of red. Small dissapearing white head. Grapefruit and pine in aroma. Flavour of grapefruit, wood, and toffee with a small hint of bread. Strong but a bit short hoppy finish.

Bottle. Great body for the style...not too light. Great hoppy balance at the end. Not too over the top at all. Good reddish-orange color and white head. Good from the bottle, but better on tap. Maybe a bit strong for sessioning.

Rogue Nation, San Francisco: Slightly rusty in color, with an off white head.  Sweet, hoppy aroma typical of IPAs.  Very mellow flavor.  It starts sort of bitter, with just a touch of sweetness wich evolves into a wild woody/mossy flavor.  Surprisingly complex for a Rogue.  I'm impressed.

Alias of Summit's Wayside Cliffhanger Ale:
My beer appeared an hazy orangy amber with small head and little lace. The aroma hint of caramel, orange zest, grapefruit, floral hops, and wheaty yeast esters. The taste is fruity and bitter, acidic with some woody character. The bitterness lingers but is not overpowering. The mouthfeel is lively and refreshing with good body for the style. Very quaffable, solid brew.

12 oz bottle.  At last, the one supposedly accessible Rogue that I've never managed to get!  Lovely copper body, creamy medium lasting head.  Nicely balanced (though not really distinctive) nose offers whiffs of caramelly malts, cedar, a bit of lemon and barnyard.  Noticeably bitter right upfront, quite pungent, low-to-medium sweetness, little fruitiness, fairly heavy in the body.  Doesn't really work all that well for me, and its a bit much for a proper session beer overall.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 If youre looking for a better bitter that beats Belhaven and Bass, this bitter might be better for you.  Bitter beers not my bag, baby, but blatantly, this beer aint bad.  Beautiful to behold and besmell.  Bitter taste, better than bad palate.  Not bad, for a better bitter beer (from a bottle).***Second rating: ditto.

The aroma smells bitter, and the beer appears to be one of weight. Its head is like an egg-white and its colour a translucent amber orange, its palate full and filling with a robust heft. The overall impression is positive, though not my favourite Rogue (I quite liked Dead Guy Ale).
Rich amber color with an off-white head that dissipates quickly.  Has a nice floral and hoppy aroma.  Sweet and bitter flavor with fruity notes.  Medium metallic palate.
Clear Orange in color with a tan head. Hoppy  aroma. American hops. Some caramel notes. Well balanced beer.
12 oz bottle. Clear orange with a nice tan head. Aroma is hoppy with carmel malty hints. Flavor is full of hops, balanced with a full chewey malt. An American ESB, I guess.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Slightly buttery, faint hop aroma.  Not much of a head.  Good solid flavor, earthy hops and butter backed up with a nice heavy mouthfeel.

A brownish red appearance with little head. Flavor was slightly bitter with some caramel and oranges. Palate was a little thin. Overall this was pretty good and good representation of an English bitter.
Brownish-red color; aroma and flavor of grapefruit and malts; nicely hopped.  Enjoyable brew.

Medium malt and hops, but little to none of the citrus from hops (maybe a bit of grapefruit). No head really... Nice color though, medium to dark amber. Gets better as it warms. I had some curry and came back to it and it improved a lot from the warming and the curry mingling. Floral scent/flavor comes forward as it warms. Not one of my favorites from the rogue folks.
Amber, with a small but fluffy head. Slightly citrus scented, but not overwhelming. A nice, stereotypical ESB flavor- it's above average, but not fantastic.

Bottle. Reddish amber classic "bitter" color. Has a homemade stale bread aroma with some floral hops. Creamy white head with very persistent lacing. Taste hits you with sweet caramelly malts and ample hop bitterness. Not too complex-thank god. a little fruity. Umm, sweet Goldings. Straightforward special bitter that is highly drinkable.

Very mild.  Served cold, to be sure--too cold, perhaps.  Big head, slightly hazy amber/copper color.  This is sympathetic to the bitter style in the English fold, though in a Northwest way.  This beer would probably be in the top 20% of English bitters by hoppiness. (on tap at Rogue Ales Public House, Portland)

Copper red hazy beer with a sweet caramel malt aroma with lite oranges. Fresh malt with a good balance of british hops (not as floral as their other beer), with a good balance and body. refreshing like breathing moutain air.
Medium sized tan head, fair retention, good lace. Hazy copper color. Raw hop nose. Medium body. Good malt to hop balance, crystal malt flavors, biscuity. Good beer! Well balanced dry finish.
Hazy yellow/golden, no head. Malty and fruity, rather mild and easy to drink.
Hazy golden, no head. Sweet and fruity, rather mild. Quite ok, but nothing that matches the best.

This brew pours with an amber-orange body topped by a medium thick off-white head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sour and slightly bitter with citrusy hop notes a touch of pine and a hint of sweet malt.  The flavor is bitter and hoppy with piney notes, slight citrus notes, and a slight metallic note.  the finish is bitter and piney.  Medium bodied and dry.

Medium amber with redish highlights.  Nice hops in the nose.  Good hops on the palate -- the malt comes through as the beer warms.  Good round mouthfeel.  Smooth and warming.  A good American take on a British ESB.
Average head atop of golden bitter ale. The nose is hops, with possible hints of citrus. The taste follows the nose but citrus is more pronounced as grapefruit. Smooth despite the hops.

Pours a clouded orange with a medium white head. Nose is hoppy and citrusy but there is a faint sweetness as well. The taste is almost pure citrus! Grapefruit and orange seem to make up the bulk of this one. Very faint malts are evident. Finishes with a light bitterness which is surprising considering how bitter the taste is.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2004 I had this on tap at the newly opened Rogue Public House in San Francisco when I was at a friend's wedding. This, along with a few other great Rogue moments were among the highlights of the food and drink portion of the trip. Hoppy as you would expect but not the detraction of the other fruit and floral flavours and aromas. Refreshing well-balanced beer that lingers quite nicely. Wish I had brought some home with me but there was only so much room....

Added infoHad this again in the guise of Summit's Wayside Cliffhanger ale (Thanks Len) and still really enjoyed the smooth, hoppy rich brown offering. Nice.

Nice. Hazy copper in color with a small white head. Lacing present. Aroma is almost whisky-like, sweet and malty. Silky smooth on the palate. Strong yet pleasant hoppy taste, consistent with the better Rogue brews. Overall, very nice.

Bright, rubyish color, with a faint white head, that slips into a narrow ring. Aroma, sweet, fruity, malty, big cherries, tangerines. Taste: great hoppiness right off, dancing along the tongue, though never too bitter, just enough. Quite malty, smooth, with fruity flavor persistent throughout the drink. Nice, sweet finish, medium body, overall excellently balance. I'm not normally crazy about bitters, but Rogue made one that's nothing but pleasure. I could drink a million of these!

Otherwise known as cliffhanger ale, bottled for summits wayside tavern.  Check it out if you're around Atlanta.  Nose is of of sweet malts, light hops, and a faint floral aroma.  Taste is nicely balanced, with a mellow malt presence up front, fading into a hop finish, with a crisp, slightly bitter aftertaste.  Clean, refreshing, and very nice.  Another well above average offering from Rogue..
A light color beer with a small head.  Very good bitter.  Nice clean finish.  I wish I bought more than just one.

Nice Rogue malt aroma(w/yeast)Orange color w/a decent head that rolls out quick/sparce lace.I liked the taste of this ale alot(decent hops)but hardly any bitterness really.A prickle on the palate at best(w/a somewhat dry finish) but overall very enjoyable.
Slighty hazy orange, light tan head. Good lacing. Big hoppy grapefruit aroma. Nice balanced malt hop flavor. Decent body. Nice beer overall.
Nice reddish copper color, with a thick creamy head.  Not a pronounced bitterness, but a smooth, almost chocolate body, with a light floral aroma.  A nice bitter.
Deep amber with a rich off white head that was fairly well lasting.  Aroma was heavy with hops as was the flavor.  Very dry to finish.  Could've been better balanced but overall a fine beer.
Cloudy dark amber with a thick off-white head.  Some fruitiness to the aroma.  Flavor had some bitterness but it was delicious.

Bubbles flowing to the top. Reddish amber pour with a slim head. Hoppy nose, some bitterness in the nose as well. Hoppy taste, with a moderate bitter aftertaste making your mouth a little dry. Maybe some dry hops are in this brew! Pretty decent from Rogue. I'm generally never disappointed from one of their brews.
Orange-red with a fruity nose.  Solid grapefruit-hopped flavor, highly bittered and malty.  Very hoppy!

Pours reddish amber with a light head and some lacing.  Nice hoppy aroma balanced well with the malts.  Floral and earthy hop flavors followed again by a mellow blend of malts. Smooth and creamy palate, a nice bitter finish. Good beer.
Nice malty back drop gives way to a shot of hops. Some nice finishing hops in there. Tasty
Not very special, not very bitter.  I was not impressed with the 'hop finish,' as it did not exist.
A brownish copper color with very little head. Lots of bubbles in the glass. Has a strong bitter taste at the end of each drink. Aroma has flowery smell. Overall, not too impressive for a bitter.

Hazy orange-copper body. Nice aroma of toffee, musky fruit, and cinnamon. Has a pronounced floral (almost soapy) bitterness with an element of aspartame in the aftertaste. However the bitterness integrates well with the malt and spice backbone here. The hoppiness and spice provide a very American twist to an English bitter. Grows on you.

Second beer served in apint glass at Rogues Brewery on The Bay, Newport, Oregon.
Clear ,lightish brown coloured beer..nice sized consistent creamy head..with very little visible carbonation.The aroma is very spicy hop for a typical English style bitter..but its pleasant.
The taste can be described as smooth to start..nice sweet malts,,then hops at the end.. this is a PNW type bitter!!
Very smooth and nice on the palate.
A drinkable beer indeed..but more like aPacific Pale than a bitter IMO.

Dark red color with a decent head that faded kind of fast but not as fast as my Vikings are fading to Oakland.Hoppy citrus aroma with a mild spice thrown in to make it all come together.The taste comes off as fruity and hoppy with only a mild spice hint but definately has a very nice hop presence along with the citrus.The after taste was citrusy and hoppy.Very nice brew,i always seem to over look these Rogues because there so easy to get,but i'm glad i bought a few finally.

Brownish orange, thin but sturdy white head. Spicy, clean aroma. A little malt up front, then veers into salt & pepper spicy bitterness. Very dry, very much an American interpretation of the "Bitter" style.
really good bitter beer.  much better than fullers esb in my opinion.  smooth, amber color, light to little head.  good aroma.  a good beer. typical rogue beer

Pours cloudy amber with a very small tan head.  Little or no lace.  A spicy/citrus aroma.  A good creamy mouthfeel with light carbonation. Not bad malt/caramel flavor with a healthy kick of bitter/citrus hops.  Some melon flavors mixed in, as well.  Not a bad bitter, but will stick to Fuller's ESB.
Looks like a nice amber ice tea, with a creamy vanilla head.  A lot of hops here, which combined with the low carbonation and caramel notes, makes for an interesting ale.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2003 Was feeling like adding a sixer of this style to my session stash, found this at Bevmo and hoped it would be a pleasant surprise. Took me three times to warm up to this brew; the first two bottles (different sessions) it wasn't bad but 3rd times a charm. Huge head, medium bodied with a strong malt character that is actually quite distinctive and enjoyable.

Wonderfully balanced beer. Dark Copper color, a tad bit on the cloudy side.  This beer is an awesome session beer.  I so wish I could get this on a regular basis.  The hops are in this beer, both flavor & bittering, and they are perfectly balanced by the malt.
Copper colored, white head. Hoppy aroma with some citrus in there. A little bit of malt followed up by a gererous amount of hops. Bitter and dry finish.
Reddish copper color, cloudy, lacing on the glass. Citrus hop nose, smooth on the palate. Lingering bitter finish.
deep amber, off white head.  earthy malt and citrus and fruity hop aroma.  caramel and some apple and melon hints with a firm earthy bitterness.  would make a fine session ale.

Had a very floral aroma, that told of the hop bite coming. Reminded me more of an IPA, with that oily, grassy taste it left on the tongue. The head was clumpy and didn't last, but the flavor was pleasing and I would drink again.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2004 Like a less brutal version of their brutal bitter.  Light amber color, large head, hoppy but not overboard, this is good stuff.

Hazy Red/orange. Fresh malt smell.  Bitter hops taste hits right away, but is soon followed and balanced out by a nice strong even caramel/earthy malt flavor.  Carries through its medium full body with a nice even bitter. Nice that it wasnt sharp. Just a real even toned beer.  Complexity is a bit lacking surprisingly, but I drank these before letting it warm to room tempurature.
Bitter, not bad.  A bit hoppier than I like.  Overally, not bad for a Rogue offering.
It is an amber color. It pours a decent head. It has a pleasant aroma of hops. The flavor is well balanced and mild.

Orange/amber with cream colored head. Smells of malt and floral hops.  Seems a little watery. Overall a muted flavor - a blend of smooth maltiness and light hoppiness.  Finishes dry and slightly bitter.
Hoppy slightly fruity aroma. Amber color with a smell head that retains very well. Hoppy start, little sweetness and a bitter finish.

This might have been an old sample considering the source, but I felt this came up a bit short.  Thin and bitter wihtout enough malt backbone or hoppy floral qualities to make it appealing.  Amazing head retention, though.  And perhaps not as bad as all that.

Medium amber body with a small white head.  It smells very good - a hint of sweetness that compliments the hoppiness.  Hoppy flavor, but not as much as I tend to like in my bitters.  But this one IS dry and bitter nonetheless.

This seems like much more of a true, British-style bitter than most American-made bitters - much more subdued hop flavors than most American hop monsters - however, that quality, along with it's watery finish, make this seem like a watered-down version of their Brutal Bitter - I love that beer, so this disappoints me - there is, however, a veryu enjoyable, chewy, bready, malt character to it that almost makes up for its shortcomings.
Deep amber in colour.  Aroma of hops, grapefruit, flowers.  Flavour was of medium bitterness, citrus, and slightly sweet.  Finishes very bitter, hoppy, and dry.  Thanks PhillyBeer.
Brownish dark color. Faint white head. Floral hoppy aroma. Very hoppy in the taste. A very bitter beer in which you must be in the mood for. Still a pretty decent beer.

Very faintly hazy amber orange colour under a medium sized short lasting head. Floral hops and light honeycomb malt and citrusy  aroma. Mild but very creamy smooth body. Decent perfumed floral hoppy bitter start. Slightly sweeter middle before back to a dry bitter hoppy finish. A really nice bitter and it really want me to try to sample the Brutal.
This was a nice bitter and suprisingly more hoppy than I expected.  Something I would try again.

Pours a medium amber/orange with a small, diminishing, frothy white head.  Carbonation is high and lacing is above average.  Medium malt; light bread: medium hops; grapefruit, flowers: light yeast; dough.  Light tastes to start and finishes heavily bitter.  Long finish.  Body is medium and felt fairly creamy to me.  Carbonation was not as pronounced in the mouth as I was expecting.  Flavor was more unbalanced than I would have thought by the aroma.  Not a very complex beer.  Skip this and go straight to the Brutal Bitter.

Redish copper color with no head or lacing. Aroma is acidic and hoppy with a malty background. Flavor is very well balanced with nice floral hops. Fruity & chocolaty. Sweet, dry and bitter on the palate. A very yummy bitter. I usually shy away from these, but leave it to Rogue to impress me.
A highly enjoyable bitter.  I do have to say that it cannot hold a candle to the Brutal Bitter, but still very enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle. No freshness date. Poured out a darker shade of copper, with a fast fading, loose white head on it. Aromas mostly of hops with a slight malt background to it. Tastes refreshing, with a noticeable hops bite to it. Slight caramel flavor as it goes down as well. Not a bad bitter if I do say so.
Cloudy amber, tan head. Nice carmel nose.Decent medium hop flavor but not enough malt to balance it. Drinkable, but nothing great
Lovely amber with scant tan head. Nice hops aroma with a hint of malt. Clean hops taste front and center, but enough malt to back it up. Not overly bitter. Excellent bitter.

Light orange color.  Head is small and thin.  Aroma of bitter hops, with a one dimensional bitter taste.  a thin, poor quality beer that has lowered the rating of one of my favorite styles.  My second disappointment from Rogue; I won't hurry to try their products again.

This beer poured a light orange color with a minimal head and lacing and a somewhat citrus-like aroma.  The taste told me that it was definitely a bitter and nothing else.  If you like bitters, this is a good bitter - I enjoyed it and actually went back for seconds.  A nice beer.

Same beautiful color as Carlow Moling's Tradional Celtic beer. Lovely, crystal clear amber brew with orange highlights. Medium-sized, lightly-tanned, frothy head. Somewhat lasting with excellent lacework.
The nose is moderately malty and hoppy with wonderful notes of English toffee and caramel; flowers, evergreen and white pepper.
Perfectly balanced flavor up front with bursts of caramel, English toffee, butter, herbs and grass. The hops win out on the backside with a very pleasant, moderately bitter jab to my right eye. That's gonna leave a mark!
Light-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Lengthy, coppery, bitter and dry finish with a hefty dose of earth and evergreen wood at the wee end.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2003 Wow, another great ale from Rogue! This is fastly becoming my favorite brewery. Beautiful amber body with a generous frothy head. Aroma is piney and I think I smell a hint of caramel. Quite hoppy and pleasantly bitter. Has a smooth full bodied mouthfeel and finishes on the dry side. Great overall ale. Could be a new regular in the fridge.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: A.k.a. Rogue Fat Heads Ale.  Very good malt combination for a good fresh bite.

That was very pleasant indeed! It pours a medium red, orange core with a dark yellow surrounding..fairly cloudy and a pearl white head which lasted 2-3 minutes. The aroma is filled with crystal malts..especially sweet with vanilla and caramel and a slight hint of peaches. The flavor has a definite peach/nectarine quality with vanilla and caramel crystal malt. It gets hoppy/bitter right in mid taste with a nice dry ending. Very malty dry ending...quite palatable with a low level of carbonation. Im happy! :)

Pours a big cloudy orange amber.  Big earthy resinous fruit nose.  Sticky beige head.  Very drinkable, smooth.  Pale malts support clean earthy hops.  Very nice session brew that is often overlooked in the Rogue line.

Clear orange amber color with a medium off white creamy head.  Crisp hop aroma.  This smells and tastes very similar to Red Hook ESB but missing a bite to make it bitter.  It is the best tasting Rogue I have had.

Nice pale reddish brown color. Medium, foamy, off-white head leaves a nice ring at the top of the glass. Pleasant aroma--very English--malty, slightly tart with hints of toffee and apples. Mild front. Medium bodied. Only the finest touch of carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel. A fruity malt backbone stands up well against a slightly dry, bitter, hoppy finish. Mild and exceedingly well balanced. Much better than many of Rogue's more visible brews.
This did not measure up in complexity to the other Rogue Bitters. Good aroma, nice appearance. Flavor starts off good but falls off.
Dark hazy burnt red, some head with good lacing.  This is a nice session ale - an adequate amount of hops (for my tastes) backed up with good fruity bready malts.  Flavors intermingled interestingly.

Lightly hazy, copper/amber color, like iced tea in color.  Creamy slightly off white head.  Diminishing down to little more than a film.  Sweet hoppy aroma, citrusy, cascade maybe.  I like the painted bottles better than the paper labels because there are the bitterness units and ingredients and all.  Nice bitter flavor, not overdone.  Lots of hoppy flavor.  Floral and citrus.  Overall good, but I would have thought this would have been more bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2003 Amber-brown with a frothy, lasting head with sticky lace. Very yeasty nose. Smooth and creamy with a soft carbonation. Chewy caramel sweetness exudes; chocolatey malts. Some interesting spicy notes... thought I tasted ginger even. Medium bitterness in the finish; nice and aromatic aftertaste. Only major complaint: some watery sensations here and there.

Beautiful orange-amber colour with a slight haziness. Sweet malty nose with some floral and citrus notes in the background. Flavour starts sweet and full, and then moves into a very pleasant, grapefuity hop bitterness. Really solid.

Kinda nice of Rogue to brew something for one of my favorite  South Side bars but the end product could have been better. This ones missing a lot everywhere. Weak aroma, light amber color, light malt flavor, watery, definitely a mild hop finish.

I tried to like this one but something was amiss.  The palate is what got me--kind of rough and possibly stale but I'm sure it was fresh.  I went through the whole six-pack and it seemed to get better but I think that even happens with Busch.  I love the Rogue beers though so I'll give it another try and re-rate if necessary.

Very nice. A "rounded" hoppiness. It has the full bitter flavour of a highly hopped beer without that sharpness that makes you burp up bitterness or a week. It balances in the finish when the bitterness settle a little and the maltyness rises up a bit to even things out quite nicely. Good stuff, tasty but gentle.

Hazy,oarnge/amber liquid,with a frothy head.Good head retntion and lace.Aroma is very inviting:buttery,bitter, sweet-maltiness. Mouthfeel is soft,with a sharpness.Sweet,juicy-malts,with a lingering,leafy/herbal,hoppy finish.Excellent finish. Enjoyed this more than the BB.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2004 Very cloudy, amber/plum colored in the glass.  Smells of sweet malts and wheat, and tastes like more of that Pacman yeast.  A good beer, though at times it's indistinguishable from the amber.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2003 Have tried this both as it's labeled, and as the Summit's Wayside Tavern version (same thing).  Sweet caramely malt aroma with some cotton candy.  Medium amber color with frothy head.  Earthy brown sugary flavor with enough hoppy bitterness, but not much.  Very smooth and unique.  Easy drinking with a crisp dry finish.  This is somewhat out of style, but it tastes very good.

Good head retention.  A vibrant amber color.  A very potent hoppy aroma and taste to back it up.  Slight maltiness that has a hint of sugar, maybe brown sugar, I don't know.  A good beer especially when it warms up a little past serving temperatures.
1/29/03:  bottle.  medium orange color.  some lacing.  hoppy aroma with some floral hintss.  tasted a little bit soapy- due to the hops.
Floral aroma mixed with earthy/dirt overtones. Subtle sweet malt finish at very end. Bitter throughout. Dark orange with quickly dissipating head.

Golden body. Quickly diminshing white head. Nice lacing.
Smells malty and slightly hoppy.
Well balanced malt/hop character. Could be a bit more full-bodied.
Fizzy.
Light amber body, small white head, Roguish nose. Roguish taste. A touch earthy, medium hops, the usual house character.

Pretty orange color with a small, white head. The aroma was more of what I think of as a traditional English bitter. There were tones of soil, hops bitterness, malty sweetness, and a touch of smoke. The flavor is similar to the aroma with a crisp hops finish. The feel is bubbly, and dry. Nice brew...very restrained for Rogue.

For what it is called, i was expecting a bitter brew, something along the lines of the anderson valley esb.  What i received was a very nice smelling brew(ipa-ish) but the taste was very very malty, not bitter at all.  I think its a great brew, but definately not really a bitter, more like their american amber ale without the hop bite.  Definately something i will try again.  I also purchased a bomber of chocolate stout and shakesphere stout-will try soon!!!

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium amber. Aroma is moderately hoppy (grapefruit), lightly
malty (toasted light bread, cookie), lightly yeasty (dough). Flavor is
moderately sweet, moderately bitter, moderately acidic. Finish is
moderately acidic, heavily bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively
carbonation, lightly astringent. Very grapefruity in aroma and flavor,
not my style.
Cloudy amber color with a small head.  Sweet hoppy aroma.  Very dry finish.  A good example of the style with a nice balance of malts and hops; very sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2004 Check this rating: I hate Rogue even more now: I found out almost five months later that this wasnt even a new beer for me. Rogue is trash.
Clear amber coloured body with ruby highlights. Aroma of caster sugar, light hops, cardboard and not much nice. Light-bodied; Funky sweet, nutty flavour that isn't pleasant. Aftertaste bitter, but not impressive. Overall, not great...and from this fact alone-we know it's a Rogue beer! I sampled this 65 cL bottle on 15-May-2004 at the May RB Party in Toronto, Ontario.

Cloudy brown in colour, great strong smell with hints of anise...great flavourful beer! A little of a hoppy ending as well!
a very plesant ale, well rounded. Nice bitterness with enough malt to back it up. This is a beer that I could drink until the wee hours of the morning.
Yum yum.  Very rich and pleasant.  Tastes very authentic to the british style, with a bit of apple fruitiness in the nose and finish.  Wonderful beer.
The color and flavor of this bitter were very enjoyable. I think it compares nicely with Youngs. The finish is dry and you dont want it to end.
Orange brown. . .medium head that lingers around the edges. . . malty brown sugar aroma. Caramel mixes nicely with the hops to offer a wonderful balance and a smooth, long, dry finish.
Very enjoyable.

Excellent beer with perfect balance for a bitter.  Small head for the style and decently carbonated with a crisp palate and hoppy finish...  Beer is somewhat murky throughout, but a great offering nonetheless.  Defintely worthy of bearing the Rogue seal...

Red-orange and slightly murky, thin white head.  Pungent citric aroma, mostly grapefruit, slightly acidic.  Maybe a touch of clove.  Definitely highlights the hops, but not in an overbearing manner.  Wouldnt this be just a bitter and not a special bitter with such a low malt presence?  Well rounded, with a nice texture.  Finishes long and dry, a nice session ale.
Copper orange color. Nice frothy head emitting piney hop aromas. Malt start crushed by hop bitterness. Long bitter finish.
One of Rogues less over the top efforts, this is a very pleasant brew, nicely balanced, with a much more mild hop profile than many of their beers.  Very good.
Cloudy orange appearance.  Aroma is of sweet malt and light hops.  Body is spritzy with long roasted hops and a touch of malt.  Quite one-sided and somewhat uninteresting.

Compared to Rogues Brutal Bitter, the Youngers is noticeably less brutal, the Willamette and Goldings playing a less dominant role in this concoction.  Malts are nicely noticeable and the aroma is sweet and beguiling.  Top notch.
A pleasant beer with a nice balance of both malt and hops.  The hops provide a nice citrus flavor and aroma on top of a creamy malt base.  Very nice and very well balanced.

Amber with a small head.  Nice floral hoppy aroma with caramel notes.  Balanced hoppy ale with sufficient malt palate.  Good clean caramel flavors with floral hop notes.  Nice and easy drinking, and one of Rogues better balanced ales.
Tap.  Dark amber color. Caramel aroma.  Smooth clean finish.
Hoppy orange colored,light malt,bitter, nothing to make me want another.

Coppery tasting, nice hop aroma-definitely cascade.  I am 
not a big fan of the ESB, and this one really tastes like a pale 
ale to me.  Ill call it an APA-almost pale ale.  Not quite the 
superior quality that I am used to from Rogue.

Nice golden body with head that leaves nice lacing.  Sweet aroma, not as bitter as Id expect.  English bitter flavor with decent balance.  Nothing distinctive, but that seems to be the goal -- a straightforward ESB.
Aroma of airplane glue.  Amber color.  Flavor is sweet and piny.  Hops add a nice bitterness to the finish.
One of my favorite ESBs. Flavor starts on the malty side but the hops soon kick in for a bitter, but balanced finish. Another great brew from Rogue.

My favorite beer from Rogue.  Brilliant red-amber color.  Aroma of crystal malts and earthy hops.  Perfect balance of malt sweetness and hop bitterness.  Good bitterness in the aftertaste.  One of the cleanest, well-balanced bitters Ive had.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 cloudy amber topped with clouds of froth..carmel apple aroma once again..Well..this ESB actually has some bitterness to speak of..amazing isnt it...so with the usual carmel appleness of ESB's, add a tad of hop bitterness and...still ordinary..some apple sweets in there though..there's still nothing special about this bitter..

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 Rerate Rogue does it again - labeled as Summits Wayside Tavern Cliff Hanger Ale. Very decent bitter - still stands up to the same ratingOriginal 3.6 Good bitter - but about average for a Rogue - which I always expect a lot out of. Not much of an aroma; pleasant dark amber color. Very hoppy of course, with a bitter aftertaste.
Amber color, medium head. Hoppy and malty. Full flavored bitter. Caramelized malts, good blend of hops. Some malt sweetness. Finish is clean. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
Hops and citrus aroma. Garnet, creamy head. Tremendous hoppy flavour, some malt notes. Very hoppy, bitter. Terrific!
Pretty good stuff. Havent tried a Rogue that i hated yet.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2003 This beer pours a cloudy orangish red color with a medium sized head that lingers on the edges and leaves a fair amount of lacings on the glass. Good aroma typical to the Rogue beers, malty and hoppy at the same time. Malty flavors up front, the hops then take over and leave you with a long, dry, slightly bitter finish. Very nice.

Poured from the bottle with a small head and little lacing.  It was the color of iced tea and had a nice malt aroma.  The flavor was a combination of malt and hops, with the hops being a little more dominant, especially in the finish.  A great example of a bitter!
A very good bitter that really stands out from the English style bitters I am accustomed to. Again, the hops are the stars here.
Clear amber color, well balanced, mild finish.
Interesting variation on the English E.S.B. has an incredible toasted malt flavor and an equal punch of hops making this a surprizingly crisp dark beer.

Nice hoppy aroma, a bit sweet and some aromatic that reminded me of coffee. Small head with little lacing on top of apple cider colored beer. Medium carb and medium watery body. Bit of cider taste but not very sweet. Nice bittering - crisp. Like a dry pils. A little weak and watery though.
Not bad went down well had it with pizza not that bitter for a bitter style beer

A bitter that is neither a bitter nor bitter. A syrupy malty smell, a clear copper colour, a diminishing head, all add up to what? A syrupy malty taste, an obligitory hop bitter, and not much else. I am unimpressed.
Bitter indeed.  A little too bitter for me.  Very very bitter.
Im with the crowd on this one. A very solid bitter.

This excellent bitter pours up with a noticeably thin head over a rich ruby-tinged brown.  The flavor is a fantastic balance of bitter hoppiness and rich malt goodness.  One of the best bitters Ive had.
Not too bad.  Light texture with a fairly moderate flavor.  Not too hoppy, but very little malt flavor.  Not one of my favorite Rogues, but still a decent beer.

Clear, copper/red color. Thin but persistent head and little lace. Nose of malt,light caramel, touch of chocolate and a moderate hop presence. Light in body but holds flavors well. Balanced flavors all at once, nothing stands out except for the moderate hoppiness, which is somewhat grassy and refreshing because its not an onslaught. The malt needs more depth but other then that, this is a good session bitter.

Nice golden color, with a thick long-lasting head. Sweet smelling. Taste is sweet to start, moving quickly to bitter. Cant find a good description for the aftertaste, but enjoyable. Overall, a good beer.

Fairly mellow for a Rogue beer. Subtle hoppiness when compared to the Brutal Bitter, this seemed like more of an attempt of Rogues to appeal to a more general audience. Nice, but nothing astonishingly different.
The bitterness didnt really make itself known in this beer, at least to me. It had more of a sweet flavor to it. Nice coloring. Has a great aroma, too.
No, no, no. Bitterness when too far, and this beer came out bad. Try the Brutal Bitter over this one, any day.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2003 Rerate: Had as the Fat Heads Ale... i liked it a lot better this time.  I'm defiantly growing appreciation for bitter beers.  A little on the hoppy side still, but i defanatly enjoyed it more this time
Sweet and bitter at the same time. Very filling, not overwhelming, great hoppy smell. Yet another good Rogue Ale...

Way overcarbonated which immediately lowered the drinking experience.  Six ounces of beer with a soft pour filled a 16 oz. glass with foam.  Flavor OK, Color OK.  Mouthfeel ruined by carbonation.  Will need to try this on tap sometime.

YSB is fairly commonly found on cask at Summits Wayside Tavern in Sandy Springs, GA, an unincorporated town that borders Atlanta to the north. Its usually on the beer list, but if you catch it in between casks, it may not actually be there. I was lucky this time and actually got a chance to try it (the last two times I was unsuccessful). The head was a thick meringue-like white foam and fought to stay around until the very end. When the beer had been brought out the head was perfect. By the time I finished my other beer and got around to tasting this one a few minutes later, it was still perfect. Even on the last few sips, the head was still there, seeming to stay in proportion to the rest of the contents of the glass. Im not a big fan of ESBs, though. I really liked Fullers with its rich maltiness. YSB seems more aggressively hopped (the hops came across as spicy/peppery) and less malty than the Fullers. I would have preferred it a little more balanced, but it wasnt bad.
About as good as it gets. Absolutely fantastic aroma and taste.  Yummmy, yummmy
Once again its another Rogue beer that makes me sit back and say yes this is what I want beer to be.  God I cant wait til I move to Oregon in 3 months!
Good stuff...medium body & moderatley sweet with a great hop profile.

Amber color with just a touch of chill haze.  Aroma of canned peaches (not in a bad way).  Fairly heavy bodied.  Very little malt  sweetness.  Very dry thoughout.  Sharp bitter finish.  Very late finish of caramel malt.  I most likely drank this a bit to cold and should have let it warm up to catch all the flavors.  But it was good and the first one always goes down quickly.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2003 Very nice color, with a hoppy nose and decent head. It starts and finishes with some hoppy bitterness.  Very "British tasting, and true to a classic bitter ale.
Hopped a little more than most ESBs but still not overpowering.  A litte citrus aroma that doesnt come through in the taste.  Earthy tones.
A very well-balanced and familiar west coast Cascades, citrus, malt APA/bitter profile. Citrus hop and caramel aroma. Sweet orange zest/gel flavor.  Satisfying palate.  Good beer.

When I poured this out of the bottle I wasnt paying attention and got some floaties in it.  My fault, but it didnt detract from this very nice beer.  There was a clean, hoppy nose.  The malt flavors were well balanced by fruity citrus notes and a nice hop bitterness in the finish.  As usual, a very nice beer from Rogue.
I continue to be impressed by the Rogue offerings.  This was very good mix with a nice bite.
Excellent balance and good hops and apple/fruit flavoring. Amber color with minimal head and lacing. Not bad at all.

Re-Rate 05/15/02: Deep amber in color, the head light beige, the lace in sheets upon the glass. Nose is malt, sweet, a bit or hint of caramel, and light floral tones also present. Front is lightly malt sweet, the top light, the finish has a pleasant hop bite, slightly dry, acidic, and a damn decent beer in my books.
I was fearful that being from the NW it would not have the balance that an ESB requires. But it had just the right restrained hop bite that and ESB should have. Well done Rogue!!
Nice aroma of hops, with a slight maltiness.  Body is very well balanced for the style.  An altogether well-made ESB.

Thick and lasting head over a beautiful butterscotch colored pint.  Aroma had plenty of earthy tones. I thought the taste was well balanced (leaning a bit toward the hops) but delicious and refreshing after a long bike ride. I will pick this up if I see it anywhere!

Clear amber. Frothy immensely dense off white head. Light carbonation. Aroma of Goldings hops, hay and light malts. Light bodied, but solid, with a defined hoppiness. Grassy and floral. Dry and clean. Light toasty malt balance. Very clean and hoppy, but this needs more malt depth to be considered a solid ESB. Finishes drier and lightly fruity, with hints of nectarine juice. Decent, but lacking by Rogues standards. Even considering its their original.
Wonderful interpretation of the style, with Rogues tradmark firmly stamped on it. Hoppier than most Bitters, but thats a good thing!!
Weird aftertaste. Hoppy and bitter. Another great Rogue Product.

autumn oak leaves orange- russet in color; it has no more head than it has hooves, but makes up for it with a typically rogue-like burgeoning bouquet of sweet woody notes, almost like a haywagon in a nice dried grassy way. toasty, some bourbon, touch of fruit, apricot perhaps. great bitterness, dryer than expected, brisk body at first, finishes mellow.  typical rogue, which is to say: excellent.
nice hoppy aroma, not enough bitterness in the flavor. bit of a sweet perfumey aftertaste.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2005 Im not sure how Rogue manages to support so many labels in its protfolio but it seems that every time I go to the store theres a new one. Many follow the same theme Rogue Red, Santas Reserve, Brutal Bitter and now YSB. Great aroma in this one, piney hops, woodsy, faint hints of smoke. Flavor is interesting with sweet caramel malts at the front that quickly gets overshadowed by a hop bitterness that runs throughout. Finishes with a good citric bitter quench. Another top rate Rogue, but having tried several similar brews from them nothing too exciting. [Update: once again typically Rogue, was disappointed to pick up Cliff Hanger and find it was the same brew, 2 points down on the overall for this reason, sorry guys, just be more honest, turning from a most loved brewery to a disliked brewery quickly]

Wow! I am Lucky! Two good beers in a row (First Shoals Pale, now this one) Not too bitter, but with qa crisp aftertaste. Slightly cloudy, highly carbonated, Medium head, and orangish color. Crisp yet has a bit of complexity to it.... hints of allspice, carrot or cinnamon?  Will gladly buy more of it... I have just discovered how great Rogue beers are, and look forward to buying more oft hem in the future. A great beer, worth finding.
Tangerine-amber color with a moderate foamy head. This english bitter has a most fruity/peachy hoppiness which becomes more flavorful as the beer warms.

ESB... more like IPA.  Very floral aroma (American hops??) with a tough of malt.  As the beer warms, the malt begins to show itself behind the significant hop flavors.  Finishes very crisp and bitter.  Deep copper color with minimal head.  A good beer, but not top notch.
Orange coloured with creamy head. Super bitter with light grape aroma.
Light amber color, small head, very bubbly. Nice hop aroma and flavor. This is like a mild version of Stone IPA or Bells Two hearted ale
I believe this is the best English-style bitter I have ever had in a bottle. One of my favorite bottled beers.
Closest thing to a true english bitter around here.  Smooth, and you can drink many of these due to the low carbonation and less sweetness.

I had always considered this to be a lost beer in Rogues immense portfolio.  But when I had it last night, it opened my eyes.  Here was a hoppy but well-balanced session bitter that Id ignored far too often.  There arent any surprises here, but the rich, earthy bitterness and sound fundamental structure make this a lovely ale.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2006 Clear light copper.  Off white foam of sticky froth.  Slightly subdued aroma of leaf, light phenol, lemon zest, buttery pale malts, and a touch of nuttiness.  Well carbonated palate, buttery, and round.  Intense buttered malts are all over the place and are perfectly complimented by earthy, hop leaf undertones.  The malt profile here is exquisite, which seems to linger for an eternity.  Slight phenolic aroma is its only downfall.  Regardless a textbook bitter.

Another great Ale from Rogue...strong apple flavor followed by a nice dose of hops that sticks around for awhile. The bitterness is balanced very well by the fruity flavor.

Another fairly good offering from Rogue.  Good hop aroma and flavor.  Balanced mouthfeel with malt on the base of the tongue and hops on the side.  Just the right amount of carbonation.  Also passed the true test of a great brew, that being, as it got warmer, it got better!  Went well with the chicken and cheese hoagie I was enjoying with it.
